title: Ketan Patel

fields.name: Ketan Patel
fields.known_for: Co-founder and CEO of Greater Pacific Capital; founder; Chairman of Force for Good; Board Trustee and Executive Director, World Academy of Art and Science; publications on geopolitics, technology and capital allocation
fields.alma_mater: London School of Economics and Political Science; City University Business School (MBA); King‚Äôs College London
fields.notable_works:
American Hegemony at a Critical Juncture, Lessons from History's Great Powers (Frontiers in Political Science, 2025)
COP28 and its Impact on the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (Frontiers in Environmental Economics, 2024)
The Master Strategist (Random House, 2005)
fields.organization: Greater Pacific Capital; Force for Good; World Academy of Art and Science

lead:
Ketan Patel¬†(born February 1962)R186¬†is a British investor, strategist and author. He is the chief executive and co-founder of the private equity firm¬†Greater Pacific Capital¬†(GPC) and the founder and chair of the Force for Good Initiativet.R147R187R146 He is a board trustee and executive director at the World Academy of Art and Science, is an advisory board member of the UN Business and Human Security Initiative at the London School of Economics and Political Science], and served on the board of the Jane Goodall Legacy Foundation and Jane Goodall‚Äôs Council of Hope. Patel served as a member of the¬†Future Capital¬†initiative convened by the United NationsR196R195¬†Prior to that he headed the Goldman Sachs Strategic Unit with an international role in strategic advice to international leaders. Patel was a partner and board member at KPMG.

His published research includes great-power transitions, global turbulence and climate policy pathways.R174R197R188

Patel is the author of¬†The Master Strategist¬†(2005).R207R201

sections.heading: Early life and education
sections.wikitext: Patel's was born in February 1962 and is British.R186¬† He grew up in East London (citation needed), and studied at the London School of Economics and City University Business School. where he graduated with a BSc in Economics from the London School of Economics and Political Science. He qualified as a chartered management accountant while working at Hewlett-Packard in finance. He went on to gain an MBA from City University Business SchoolR58 and earned an  MSc in neuroscience from King's College London.R62R190

sections.heading: Career
sections.wikitext:
Early career

Patel began his career at Hewlett-Packard (citation needed). He went on towork in management consulting at KPMG where he became a partner, and went on to join the board,

Goldman Sachs

He was a managing director at join Goldman Sachs, where he established the bank‚Äôs Strategic Group, advising international leaders on the potentialR58¬†, and was been described in a rare interview as the bank‚Äôs ‚Äúchief futurologist‚Äù. R190R194 He left the bank to establish his own consultancy and investment business.R58

Greater Pacific Capital

Patel is the co-founder and chief executive of the investment firm Greater Pacific Capital (GPC)R147R187¬†and e is a designated member of Greater Pacific Capital LLP since April 2005.R186¬†The firm had an India- and China-focused investment strategy.R203¬† Business Standard reported that Greater Pacific Capital acquired a stake in Indian investment bank Edelweiss Capital at a valuation of US$100 million. Media coverage of GPC has also included reporting on an India-focused fundraise and portfolio investments in education technology, electric vehicles and artificial intelligence.R147R150R151R153

Force for Good Initiative

Patel is the founder and chairman of Force for Good, which was established to support the UN Secretary-General's roadmap for sustainable development and examined and engaged 125 global financial institutions and 100 technology companies in its research programmes.R187R188¬†Force for Good publishes report series including¬†Capital as a Force for Good¬†and¬†Technology as a Force for Good, where Patel is the lead author.R178R179¬† UNCTAD and the UN Office for Partnerships were the hosts of Future Capital which preceded the establishment of the initiativeR204¬†The International Institute for Sustainable Development's SDG Knowledge Hub describes the technology report as indicating that ‚Äútechnology and the technology industry are likely the deciding factors determining whether the SDGs and human security needs are met‚Äù.R180 Patel launched a report on the idea of a World Investment Plan at COP30 in the opening panel of the United Nations Climate Change Global Innovation Hub,.xxx

Institutional and advisory roles

UNCTAD and the United Nations Office of Partnerships hosted the Future Cpaital Initiative to develop recommendations on changing the way capital and finance are allocated in support of the 2030 Agenda, in which Patel was a member ; and was asked to define and lead the initiative's finance working group.R195R196¬†Patel served as a board trustee and executive director of the World Academy of Art and Science and has published on geopolitics and global turbulence with its journal¬†Cadmus.R176¬†He is a member of the advisory board of the United Nations [Business Security initiative] at the London School of Economics and Political Science.R193¬†He was a member of the SDSN Europe Senior Working Group on the European Green Deal and the SDGs.R198

sections.heading: Ideas and contributions
sections.wikitext:
Patel's published work has focused on great power transition, systemic risk and transition in the international order, with particular emphasis on the interaction of geopolitics, technology and capital allocation.

Great-power transitions and the international order

in an examination of American Hegemony, Patel and co-authors argued that the United States in common with a history‚Äôs major powers is passing through an identifiable life-cycle phases evidencing common critical indicators of decline and assessed implications for U.S. strategic positioning and alliance structures.R174









Global turbulence and polycrisis frameworks

In 2025, Patel co-authored a series of¬†Cadmus¬†articles proposing frameworks for understanding "global turbulence" and policy responses to interlinked crises across security, development and governance.R176R175

Cognitive sovereignty and information-era security

In a 2025 paper Patel examined what he termed "cognitive empires" wherein power projection shifts from a primary focus on land to minds through algorithms underlying AI-enabled systems, undermining individual agency, sovereignty and security.R177 At the AI Impact Summit 2026 in Delhi, Patel launched a report Technologies Shaping the Future.xxx and presented the idea of Cognitive Empires, the rivalry between the U.S. and China around six systemic technologies, and the need for Europe and India to form a third axis to maintain autonomyxxx

Technology and development pathways

In the Force for Good series of reports, Patel and collaborators identify 19 core technologies common to countries and companies competing for power and value XXX. They argue that digital technologies in particular could materially accelerate progress toward addressing development targets when paired with governance and investment frameworks.R179R180 The World Investment Plan report produced in 2025 was presented at the side event forum hosted by Pvblic at the United Nations in interim form during the United Nations General Assumbly,xxx and in final form at COP30 (citation as above).

International capital allocation for development

Patel and co-authors have argued that meeting the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is constrained less by the absolute availability of capital than by capital allocation mechanisms, incentives and risk.R161¬†A paper based on the report published in Cadmus¬†was a "seminal" and "highly novel" contribution in an article responding to it.R184 In a Reuters OpEd in [2024], Patel argued that the key to closing the worldwide development gap was scaled implementation of proven solutions not a primary focus on capital mobilisation.R188R189

Climate transition policy and pathways

In a 2024 perspective paper, Patel and co-author, Hansmeyer, described five climate transition scenarios and socioeconomic pathways.R197

Master Strategy

Patel‚Äôs book, The Master Strategist, was published by Random House and¬†includes a foreword from Nelson MandelaR194R191R192. The book proposes that given systemic level changes from world events, strategies need to become systemic too.xxx

sections.heading: Influence and reception
sections.wikitext:
The Master Strategist was endorsed by Nandan Nilekani former CEO of Infosys thought it was ‚Äúa book on life itself‚Äù, Nobuyuki Idei, former Chairman and CEO of Sony Corporation, felt it, ‚Äúwill serve as the reference work of strategy for many years to come.‚Äù Scott Kapnick, former CEO, Goldman Sachs International, and Co-Head Investment Banking, appreciated the ‚Äúinsights and wisdom‚Äù can be applied to business, politics and life.R206R181¬†  The IMFO¬†journal (Institute of Municipal Finance Officers) noted, ‚ÄúXXX‚Äù.R185 The use of metaparadoxes, aphorisms and frameworks rather than disclosure of companies or situations addressed is was felt to be a shortcoming.xxx  The Times interview ended with the thought that ‚ÄúThe book in particular gives the impression he has somehow channelled the voice of God‚Äù.xxx

The ideas presented by Patel on Cognitive Empires and sovereignty and agency from the report Technologies Shaping the Future, at the AI Impact Summit 2026, were commented on by Glenn Gaffney, former Director of Science and Technology at the Central Intelligence Agency, with the view that sovereignty ‚Äúlies with whoever owns the infrastructure through which your attention, your action, your decision making‚Äù. On the same presentation, Garry Jacobs, President of the World Academy of Art and Science, agreed that ‚ÄúWe're being manipulated .. We're being told what we want to be told‚Äù but added that AI ‚Äúis a positive great opportunity‚Äù. Shaurya Doval, founder of the India Foundation, observed that ‚Äúcapital sovereignty‚Äù was a critical ingredient in addition to cognitive.

Stefan Brunnhuber described Patel and co-authors' paper on funding the SDGsxxx as "seminal" and "highly novel" in an article responding to its argument while highlighting alternative solutions.R184

UNCTAD‚Äôs New York Chief, reporting on the Future Capital initiative described Patel‚Äôs work as "unprecedented" in defining activities that could make an entity or industry a "force for good" and described the project as having potential to support UN work on advancing investment in the SDGs.R196

sections.heading: Personal life
sections.wikitext: Patel lives in London and has an interest in meditation.R58

sections.heading: Selected works
sections.wikitext:

Independent review of The Master Strategist (IMFO)
Invited speaker and interview subject in recorded forums (SALT, CES, WAAS, COP29 and other conferences)
Named as CEO/co-founder of Greater Pacific Capital in business press coverage (e.g., Mint; The Business Times)
Peer-reviewed publication in Frontiers in Political Science (2025)
Publisher pages include endorsement quotations from prominent public figures for The Master Strategist
Reuters author page and published Reuters sustainability commentaries
UNCTAD coverage identifying Patel as lead of the Future Capital initiative (2019‚Äì2020)
